CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: Does close cooperation with Muslim nations and the American Muslim community actually yield more intelligence benefits than cooperation with non-Muslim nations and communities?

Can you provide evidence from your experience working with NATO and Muslim-majority nations that suggests their cooperation with the US is more effective under Democratic leadership than under Republican leadership?

If working closely with Muslim nations to gather intelligence is crucial in combating terrorism, why should we assume that Donald Trump's dismissive approach towards Muslims would be any less effective than Clinton's inclusive approach?
Does the effectiveness of intelligence gathering from Muslim-majority nations justify the potential risks associated with alienating them due to Donald's rhetoric?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: If providing paid family leave, earned sick days, affordable childcare, and debt-free college are indeed achievable through making the wealthy pay their fair share and closing corporate loopholes, then why have these policies not been implemented yet despite the repeated calls for them?
Can you provide evidence from your previous public policies or actions as a public figure that demonstrate your commitment to implementing the policies you are advocating for tonight?

If Clinton advocates for corporate accountability to ensure the wealthy pay their fair share, why should she not also support policies that redistribute wealth from top executives to working-class individuals who contribute to corporate profits?

If Clinton's proposed policies are intended to benefit the working class, then shouldn't her own history of profiting from her husband's presidency and speaking fees also be subject to scrutiny and reform?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: If implementing the policies that Clinton claims failed in the past would indeed lead to a decline in the economy, then why would Clinton's proposed policies, which have also been tried before, be expected to yield a different outcome?
Can you provide a specific, peer-reviewed study that supports the assertion that independent experts have looked at and agreed with your proposed policies?

If the economic policies that led to the 2008 financial crisis were deemed a "hoax" by experts, would it be reasonable to consider climate change a legitimate threat if Donald Trump dismisses it as a Chinese hoax?

If the economy has indeed recovered, why do we need to continue with policies that Clinton claims worked, when the alternative proposed by her opponent may be more effective in addressing the current economic challenges?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: If Iran had already mastered the nuclear fuel cycle and built covert facilities under the Bush administration, would the sanctions imposed by the US under Clinton's leadership have been the primary cause of Iran's halt in nuclear development?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb when you became Secretary of State?
If NATO invoked Article 5 in response to a terrorist attack, why wouldn't it also invoke it in response to a nation acquiring nuclear capabilities?
If NATO invoked Article 5 after 9/11, but hasn't invoked it in response to Iran's nuclear program, does that indicate a double standard in the alliance's commitment to collective defense?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: If Clinton's diplomatic approach was so successful in achieving a deal with Iran, then why did she not use the same approach to address other international conflicts during her time in the Senate?

Do you have any evidence that the sanctions imposed by Clinton's coalition were the sole reason for Iran's willingness to negotiate, rather than other factors such as economic pressure or international isolation?

If Clinton's approach to diplomacy with Iran, which involved a multi-year coalition-building effort, can be considered effective, wouldn't her approach to dealing with North Korea, a country with an even more aggressive nuclear program, require a similarly patient and diplomatic strategy?
If sanctions were sufficient to drive Iran to the negotiating table, then why is Clinton implying that they were insufficient to prevent North Korea's nuclear program?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: If a commander-in-chief being taunted is a cause of instability, then does that not also suggest that the ability to withstand criticism is a crucial aspect of the temperament required for the position?

Can you provide evidence from a reputable psychological study that supports the notion that being "taunted" is a reliable indicator of a person's temperament unsuitability for a high-stress position like the presidency?
If a commander-in-chief can be criticized for their temperament, why should a public figure be exempt from criticism for their temperament?
If a commander-in-chief is expected to remain calm under pressure, then shouldn't they be able to handle being "taunted" without losing their composure?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's concern that terrorists acquiring nuclear material pose a threat to global security if Clinton's opponent has a cavalier attitude towards nuclear weapons?
Can you provide evidence from a reputable source that Clinton's assessment of nuclear weapons as the number-one threat is supported by objective international security analysis?
If a nation's cavalier attitude towards chemical weapons is not considered a threat, why should a nation's cavalier attitude towards nuclear weapons be considered the number-one threat?

If a nuclear-armed North Korea poses the number-one threat, then why is it not a higher priority to address its nuclear ambitions than to focus on preventing terrorists from acquiring nuclear material?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: What effect would acknowledging the problem have on the actions taken to address it?
Can you provide any credible source or scientific evidence to support your claim that the given statement effectively describes the problem?
If the American system is compared to a "plantation," why does that not imply the same systemic injustices are still in place for those who were enslaved or descendants of enslaved people?
If the description accurately portrays the problem, then what concrete steps does it suggest to resolve it?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's lack of an alternative plan to the deal with Iran undermine his criticism of the current deal and diminish his ability to lead the world with strength and in accordance with his values?
Can you provide any evidence that the Iranian nuclear deal has been "very successful" in giving the US access to facilities it never had before?

If Clinton's insistence on secrecy surrounding her plan to defeat ISIS undermines her credibility on leading the world with strength and in accordance with values, then how can she expect the world to rely on her leadership?
If the Iranian deal has been very successful, does that justify its potential risks and uncertainties when compared to the unknowns of a hypothetical alternative proposed by Clinton's opponent?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: Will investing in solar panels and clean energy necessarily lead to a significant boost in the economy and job creation, or are there other factors at play?

Can you provide any empirical evidence from a reputable economic source that supports the claim that deploying a half a billion more solar panels and building a new modern electric grid will be enough to "get the economy really moving again"?

If investing in a half a billion more solar panels and building a new electric grid can create a lot of jobs and new economic activity, why can't the government also invest in job creation and economic growth in other sectors that are not primarily focused on renewable energy?

If deploying a half a billion solar panels and building a new grid will create jobs and stimulate the economy, then why did the previous administration's economic policies, which you claim led to trouble, not lead to significant economic growth despite having the same resources available?

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: Does the increase in American exports under Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State necessarily translate to a direct cause of creating new jobs, or are there other factors at play?
Can you provide evidence from your tenure as secretary of state that a 30 percent increase in American exports globally directly led to the creation of new jobs in the United States?

If Clinton's record of supporting some trade agreements while opposing others is indicative of her nuanced approach to trade policy, why would she not apply a similar standard to other complex economic issues?
If she voted against CAFTA but claims to hold the same standards for all trade deals, how can her previous vote be reconciled with her current stance?

CLINTON_39.input:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: Does having held the title of secretary of state necessarily translate to more effective foreign policy experience than serving as a senator?

Can you provide any credible evidence or specific policy achievements from your time as secretary of state that demonstrate your qualifications for the position, rather than simply stating your title?
If being a senator and secretary of state are qualifications for the presidency, why should experience in those roles be given more weight than, say, experience as a businessman or reality TV star?
Just because you've held a position of power, does that necessarily mean you've been effective in it?

CLINTON_55.input:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: If investing in new jobs and rising incomes rather than tax cuts leads to a healthier economy, then why do the proposed tax cuts have the potential to add $5 trillion to the debt?

Do you have any credible economic research that supports your assertion that tax cuts would not stimulate job creation and economic growth, as opposed to other economic theories that suggest they can be beneficial?
If investing in tax cuts that add to the national debt is seen as a means to stimulate the economy, then why wouldn't increasing government spending be a similarly effective method?
If the economy is the top priority, then why would implementing tax cuts that add to the debt be considered a more effective way to stimulate economic growth than investing in other areas?

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's plan actually create 10 million jobs as claimed, or is that a misleading estimate based on flawed assumptions or methodology?
Can you provide a peer-reviewed study that supports the claim that your economic plan would create 10 million jobs while your opponent's plan would lose us 3.5 million jobs and lead to a recession?
If Clinton's book is a comprehensive plan with a robust set of proposals, why does she need to rely on third-party analysis to support her claims of job creation and debt management?
If Clinton's book outlines a plan for "strong growth" and "sustained growth," why does she claim that her opponent's plan would lead to a recession and a significant job loss?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: If raising taxes on the wealthy and corporations would actually lead to the wealthy and corporations paying their fair share to support the country, then why would Clinton's proposal not add a penny to the debt, as he claims?
Can you provide a detailed, peer-reviewed economic analysis that supports your claim that raising taxes on the wealthy would not add a penny to the national debt?
If the wealthy are expected to pay their fair share to support the country, would they not also be expected to contribute to the nation's debt?

If your proposal to cut regulations for small businesses is so beneficial, then why would it be necessary to raise taxes on the wealthy to fund it, rather than allowing the economic growth it would spur to offset the costs?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's proposed tax system, which rewards work over financial transactions, actually cause more economic growth and job creation, or is it simply a means to redistribute wealth?

Can you provide evidence from the historical record that your economic policies have been more effective than Trump's in creating jobs and rising incomes, especially considering the current state of the US economy?

If a 1 percent of the world's population in the United States having significant wealth and influence is seen as a problem, why is it not similarly concerning for the 95 percent of the global population that the US trades with to have significant economic influence over the remaining 5 percent?

If Clinton's economic plan is more effective at growing the economy and creating jobs, why does she still believe that a significant portion of the population, such as the top 1%, would benefit from her proposed tax system?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's experience with his father's small business influence his economic policy stance that prioritizes the middle class over the wealthy?
Can you provide evidence from your business experience or any scientific study that proves the assertion that investing in the wealthy leads to overall economic growth?
If a wealthy businessman like Clinton's opponent started a business with family connections, would that inherently disqualify him from advocating for policies benefiting the middle class?

If his own father's success as a small businessman through hard work is a more relatable model, why does Clinton consider it more effective to focus on the middle class rather than wealthy individuals like his opponent?

CLINTON_85.input:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: If the proposed tax changes do not incentivize repatriation, then what alternative measures could the administration implement to encourage companies to bring back the stranded overseas funds?
Can you provide evidence from your economic experts that your tax proposals will indeed cause the repatriation of money currently stranded overseas, as you claimed?
If companies are expected to repatriate funds when tax rates are lowered, why wouldn't they do so under the current tax rates, as suggested by Clinton?
If corporate tax rates are not changing, then why should we expect the repatriation of money that's currently stranded overseas under Clinton's plan?

CLINTON_87.input:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: Does the existence of the "Trump loophole" actually benefit the general public or primarily serve the interests of the business it was created for?
Can you provide a credible source to support your claim that your proposed policy would indeed benefit the public, rather than just your business interests?
If the Clinton administration considers a loophole that benefits Trump as problematic, why would it be acceptable for the Clinton administration to exploit a loophole that benefits themselves?
If supporting your proposal would indeed work to our benefit, then isn't that essentially admitting that the current system has been disadvantageous to us, thus validating the need for a change?

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance their—their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's proposed middle-class-focused economic strategy actually have the potential to reverse the economic downturn caused by the trickle-down policies she criticizes?

Can you provide empirical evidence from peer-reviewed studies to support your assertion that broad-based, inclusive growth is a more effective economic strategy than trickle-down economics in the United States?
If reducing taxes on the wealthy led to economic instability in 2008 and 2009, does it not follow that increasing taxes on the wealthy could potentially lead to economic growth?

If top-down economic policies are so ineffective, then why should we rely on the wealthy to voluntarily contribute to rebuilding the middle class when they have historically shown a lack of willingness to do so?

CL_57.input:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is fool’s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: If ignoring moral hazard leads to the creation of "fool's gold," then what are the long-term economic consequences for individuals and the overall economy?
Can you provide a credible economic model or empirical evidence that supports the claim that suppressing moral hazard in lending and borrowing always results in the creation of "fool's gold"?
If suppressing moral hazard in lending and borrowing results in illusory wealth, can the same be said of suppressing moral hazard in other economic systems, such as subsidies or government bailouts?
If suppressing moral hazard leads to "fool's gold," does that not justify ignoring it in order to achieve perceived financial gains?

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Does the potential risk of peanut reactions on flights justify the restriction of passenger freedom to choose from a variety of snacks, even if it may inconvenience some consumers who do not have a peanut allergy?

As a physician with expertise in food allergies, do you have any data or studies that demonstrate a significant increase in peanut-related anaphylaxis incidents on flights where peanuts are served versus flights where they are not?

If banning peanuts on airlines is considered a necessary measure to prevent life-threatening reactions, then shouldn't restrictions also be placed on other potentially hazardous substances like latex or shellfish that can cause severe allergic reactions?

If peanut products are truly necessary for airline food options, then why have many airlines already successfully eliminated peanuts from their in-flight menus without reported significant customer dissatisfaction?

Elmattador__92.input:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: Does the increasingly hostile tone of the GOP debates actually end up hurting the Republican party's chances of winning the election, leading to a loss of votes for the eventual nominee?
Do you think the tone and tenor of the GOP debates are representative of the party's values or are they indicative of a broader societal issue with American politics?
If the tone of the Republican debates is seen as a turn-off to voters, does that suggest that a similar tone in Democratic debates could similarly alienate potential supporters?
If the current Republican debates are indeed alienating voters, doesn't that suggest a fundamental flaw in the party's approach rather than a problem with the Democratic nominee?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: If peanut allergy reactions can be unpredictable and potentially life-threatening, should airlines be required to implement stricter measures to minimize airborne peanut particles in cabins to protect passengers with severe allergies?

Do you have a medical expert that can guarantee an EpiPen will be effective in preventing a fatal peanut allergy reaction in an airplane cabin where airborne particles may be circulating for an extended period?

If a person with a peanut allergy is considered to have a legitimate disability, why should they be expected to have the same career opportunities as someone without such a disability, especially if those opportunities require frequent travel and exposure to potential allergens?

If a severe food allergy is considered a disability that restricts a person's freedom to travel and work, why should individuals with a peanut allergy be required to tolerate the risks associated with flying when other passengers with disabilities are accommodated and protected?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: If frequent-flyers with medical conditions that require rescue medication are already taking precautions to minimize their risk, why should the risk of peanut allergies necessitate a more drastic solution, such as banning peanuts from flights?
Do you have any medical evidence to support the claim that wearing face masks and clothing can effectively minimize the risk of anaphylaxis in a confined space like an airplane?

If frequent flyers with medical conditions requiring rescue medication are allowed to minimize risks to themselves by wearing face masks and carrying medication, why should peanut allergy sufferers not be allowed to take similar precautions to minimize their risks on flights?

If banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation is seen as an overreach, then why should those with peanut allergies be expected to accept less stringent accommodations, such as voluntarily reserved seating blocks, instead of more comprehensive safety measures?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.input:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: If the DOJ has already determined that an assault weapons ban won't significantly impact homicide rates, then what alternative solutions proposed by Bernie or others would be more effective in addressing gun violence?
Can you provide any credible evidence from the DOJ's 2019 report that supports your claim that an assault weapons ban will have no effect on addressing homicide rates in the US?
If a lack of effectiveness in banning assault weapons is acknowledged, why would it be deemed a viable solution to gun violence when other alternatives are considered?
If the DOJ's findings on the ineffectiveness of an assault weapons ban are accurate, why do you propose dismissing it as a potential solution to gun violence, despite Bernie's support for it?

HOLT_126.input:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: Does the unconstitutionality of stop-and-frisk policies in New York disproportionately affect the crime rates in predominantly black and Hispanic communities, thereby causing a potential rise in crime rates?

Can you provide empirical evidence from the court ruling or academic research that suggests stop-and-frisk disproportionately targeted black and Hispanic young men specifically, rather than other demographics or groups?

If stop-and-frisk targeted black and Hispanic young men in New York, would it not be analogous to other policing practices that disproportionately affect other marginalized groups, such as Muslim Americans or low-income communities?

If stop-and-frisk was deemed unconstitutional for unfairly targeting specific racial groups, then doesn't the argument for implementing similar policies elsewhere rely on a flawed assumption that certain demographics are inherently more suspicious?

HOLT_239.input:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: Does changing the policy on first use of nuclear weapons increase the likelihood of a nuclear conflict, thereby undermining national security?

Can you provide a credible source to support the claim that President Obama seriously considered changing the nation's longstanding policy on first use of nuclear weapons, or was that a speculative assertion?

If a nation's policy of first use of nuclear weapons is compared to a personal decision to use deadly force, would that policy not be analogous to a right to self-defense, thereby justifying its continued use?
If we're considering a shift in policy on first use of nuclear weapons, wouldn't that undermine the deterrent effect that the current policy is intended to maintain?

HOLT_94.input:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money to—who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of transparency in Trump's tax returns undermine the legitimacy of his claims to represent the interests of the American people?
Can you provide any evidence from a reputable source that releasing tax returns is a standard practice for presidential nominees that has been consistently followed for decades?

If nominees releasing their tax returns is a standard expectation to ensure transparency and eliminate potential conflicts of interest, should not all presidential candidates, regardless of party affiliation, be held to the same standard?
If releasing tax returns is crucial for voters to know about potential conflicts of interest, why should the burden of paying taxes be a valid reason for withholding that information from the public?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "they’re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes I’d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
it’s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: Does intervening in families with high levels of aggression and violence necessarily lead to them becoming more effective parents, rather than potentially causing further harm or resentment?

Don't you think that intervening in families with high levels of aggression and violence is a more complex issue than simply imposing the right levels, and may require more nuanced approaches than a blanket intervention?
If families with high aggression and violence are subject to intervention, why should families with similar needs not be subject to similar support systems?

If some families are deemed too violent to help, doesn't that imply that intervening in their lives could be more beneficial than not intervening at all, potentially contradicting the notion that only those who are capable of reforming should be helped?

17th_knight__247.input:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it
republicans used to get mocked and laughed at when they said that illegal immigrants would be getting obamacare coverage"

cqs.cq: If undocumented immigrants are already contributing to the society and workforce, does their access to healthcare coverage necessarily cause a significant financial burden on the US healthcare system?
Can you provide evidence from a reputable source that shows illegal immigrants are currently receiving Obamacare coverage under Republican policies, as you claim was previously mocked?

If illegal immigrants are granted access to a government healthcare program, would this not set a precedent for other groups, such as non-citizens or those who do not work, to also receive similar benefits?
If they are already contributing to society and working, why does the fact that they are undocumented make them deserving of xenophobic exclusion from healthcare coverage?

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: Would allowing passengers to deplane during gate holds without CBP screening, as proposed, actually decrease the likelihood of tarmac delays or merely shift the inconvenience to another part of the airport process?

Can you provide any credible evidence from the aviation industry or scientific research that supports the assertion that deplaning during tarmac delays without CBP screening is a safe and effective solution for passengers?
If a military member can deplane during gate holds for customs screening without violating security protocols, why can't civilians be allowed to do the same during tarmac delays?
If the military can successfully manage deplaning during gate holds without compromising security, then why can't commercial airlines implement a similar system to minimize tarmac delays?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: If charging for carry-on pets with no corresponding increase in airline-provided pet care services is allowed, do you think it's fair to charge for other items necessary for passenger health and comfort?

Can you provide any credible medical evidence to support the claim that the current seat size and configuration in commercial airlines poses a significant health risk to passengers, justifying the elimination of fees for items necessary due to these factors?

If airlines are expected to accommodate passengers with physical disabilities by providing adequate space for mobility, why shouldn't they be required to provide a similar level of accommodation for passengers who cannot afford to pay for basic necessities like seat size and pet travel?

If seat size and configuration are a legitimate health concern, why should airlines be allowed to charge extra for items necessary due to factors like seat size, but not for items like pet fees that are also subject to airline-imposed constraints?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: If banning peanuts and tree nuts on flights would indeed make air travel safer for individuals with severe allergies, then why have airlines and regulatory bodies not implemented this measure despite the documented risks and the personal pleas of parents like AllergyDad?
Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that a blanket ban on peanuts and tree nuts on flights would significantly reduce the risk of anaphylaxis on airplanes?

If airline passengers are prohibited from bringing on board hazardous materials like lithium batteries that can cause fires, why should peanut products, which can cause anaphylaxis, be allowed on flights?

If airline travel poses such a significant risk to children with severe allergies, why not ban other common in-flight hazards that can cause death, such as smoking or certain types of food, instead of targeting peanuts specifically?

AngelComa__638.input:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: Does a candidate's ability to provide detailed information on their website necessarily translate to effective leadership and decision-making in office?
Can you provide evidence from a reputable source that suggests a politician's plan not being discussed in full detail during a debate is an unusual occurrence?
If a presidential candidate's website is considered a reliable source of information, then why is it not similarly trusted when a non-politician provides a concise explanation of their plan?
If his plan is supposedly "all there" on his website, then why did he need to resort to a dismissive and unprofessional outburst to defend it?

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: Does the variable and potentially inaccurate quality of information from airline customer service departments exacerbate the psychological effects of flying, thereby increasing the risk of serious reactions in passengers with allergies?
Can you provide any credible evidence that suggests airlines are capable of consistently monitoring and regulating their customer service effectively without external oversight?

If airlines are incapable of providing accurate and reliable information about peanuts on flights, can they be trusted to safely accommodate passengers with other severe allergies or medical conditions?
If the airline industry is so incapable of monitoring itself, then why would we trust them to handle potentially life-threatening situations like peanut allergies on their own?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: Do the opponents' refusal to consider the studies on accommodations and their dismissal of potential compromises demonstrate a disproportionate influence of the majority's interests over the needs of minority groups?

Can you name a single study published in a reputable medical journal that supports the claim that opponents of accommodations are driven by a "tyranny of the majority" mentality rather than a genuine concern for evidence-based policy?
If the opponents of accommodations are aware of research supporting their stance but dismiss it due to prejudice, would this not be a form of tyranny of the majority, as feared by the Founders?
If the opponents of accommodations are so well-informed about the studies supporting them, why do they refuse to engage in a discussion about compromise positions?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: Does the presence of peanut allergens in recirculated air in aircraft cabins pose a significant enough risk to warrant restrictions on serving peanuts on flights, given the relatively low risk of anaphylactic shock compared to other public environments?
Can you provide a scientific study or credible source that supports your claim that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings?

If peanut allergens in recirculated air pose a significant risk to those with severe allergies, why do we not see similar restrictions on eating peanuts in other enclosed public spaces where allergens are also present?
If the air onboard an airliner is indeed cleaner than most public buildings, as you claim, why should peanut-sensitive travelers be forced to choose between their health and flying?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: If most reported peanut allergies are indeed imagined, then would not eliminating peanuts on airplanes actually increase the risk of severe reactions due to unprepared passengers being unaware of their supposed allergies?

Do you have any credible medical studies that demonstrate a significant correlation between in-flight peanut consumption and the risk of severe allergic reactions, rather than anecdotal claims and hypothetical scenarios?
If most food allergies are indeed "completely imagined," as howie suggests, then why are peanuts singled out as a public health menace, while other seemingly harmless foods are not?
If most food allergies are completely imagined, then why should the rarity of severe peanut allergies justify the blanket prohibition of peanuts on airplanes for everyone else?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: If airlines are allowed to charge exorbitant taxes in addition to the ticket price, why should retail businesses not be permitted to implement similar pricing tactics, such as frequent price changes or bundling higher-priced goods, without facing legal consequences?
Do you have any evidence that the airline industry is more prone to bait and switch tactics than other retail businesses, such as the ones you own?

If airline pricing practices are considered deceptive and bait-and-switch tactics, why shouldn't retail businesses that employ similar pricing strategies be held to the same standards of transparency and consumer protection?
If airlines are guilty of lying with deceptive pricing, then shouldn't retailers be held to the same standards of transparency and honesty in their pricing practices?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldn’t encourage it for ourselves either
That’s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, there’s a danger I think when you kind of say, “The poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.”
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they haven’t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: Doesn't the fact that wealthy individuals have historically driven social progress through investment imply that encouraging them to take on more risk and provide more loans would also lead to greater social benefits?
Can you provide evidence that wealthy individuals have consistently demonstrated a willingness to take on more risk and invest in productive endeavors rather than solely consumer credit?
If wealthy individuals are capable of driving social progress through productive investments, why do their failure to do so not constitute a form of moral culpability?
If the wealthy are capable of driving social progress through productive investments, why do they instead opt for risk-averse consumer credit that perpetuates inequality?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries – and now the sufferers – of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
“Well, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?”
And you do actually want to say, “Money doesn’t grow on trees.”"

cqs.cq: Does the assumption that the economy can be sustained through credit and consumption mask the underlying structural issues that led to the current economic state?
Can you provide evidence that the people who took sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries of the policies you're referring to?

If the economic struggles of those who took sub-prime mortgages are attributed to a political strategy, does that imply that the struggles of those who took on unsustainable debt in the 2008 housing market crash were also a result of a deliberate policy?
If the sub-prime mortgage policy was indeed a deliberate strategy, then doesn't that imply that the government intentionally created a situation where people would suffer financially?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of Clinton's tax returns being released during his presidential campaign imply that he is hiding information about his financial situation or charitable giving?
Do you have any credible evidence that the IRS has explicitly stated there is no prohibition on releasing tax returns while under audit?

If a presidential candidate's tax returns are a legitimate means of evaluating their financial honesty, why should voters not also scrutinize the tax returns of other candidates, such as Clinton herself, who has similarly kept her returns private?

If tax returns are a standard requirement for presidential candidates and can reveal personal financial information, then does the lack of transparency in Trump's tax returns imply that he has something to hide?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: Does addressing the systemic issues Clinton mentions, such as unequal education and treatment in the criminal justice system, actually cause a significant reduction in racial tensions and police-community conflicts?

Do you have any concrete, data-driven evidence to support the claim that race still determines where people live, what education they receive, and how they're treated in the criminal justice system to a greater degree than other factors such as socioeconomic status or personal choices?
If the presence of racial disparities in the criminal justice system is a symptom of deeper societal issues, why would addressing these disparities alone be enough to dismantle systemic racism?
If we acknowledge that race still determines too much in our country, then why do we not have a comprehensive plan to eradicate these systemic inequalities rather than just calling for reform?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: Does implementing Clinton's proposed platform for reforming the criminal justice system necessarily lead to a reduction in the gun epidemic that disproportionately affects young African-American men?

Can you provide evidence from your experience as a presidential candidate that you have successfully worked with law enforcement and community leaders to implement reforms in a city or state that have led to a significant reduction in crime rates and improved community-police relations?

If the gun epidemic disproportionately affects young African-American men, why would Clinton's platform fail to address the systemic issues that contribute to this disparity, such as poverty and lack of access to education and job opportunities?

If the gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African-American men, then why does your proposed platform focus on restoring trust and working with the police, rather than prioritizing stricter gun control measures to address this specific issue?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: If Donald Trump's portrayal of black communities is so inaccurate and ineffective, as Clinton suggests, then why did violent crime rates actually increase in some areas during the time period when community policing was implemented?

Can you provide any evidence from the studies or data you're referencing to support the claim that community policing has been effective in reducing crime rates in black communities, especially considering the criticisms of stop-and-frisk being ineffective yet constitutional in some contexts?

If the Clinton administration's community policing strategy was effective in reducing crime rates, why did stop-and-frisk policies, which were also aimed at keeping communities safe, have such devastating and disproportionate impacts on young African-American and Latino men?

If stop-and-frisk was deemed unconstitutional due to its ineffectiveness in reducing crime, doesn't implementing similar policies to address public safety concerns in black communities undermine Clinton's claim that there are "right ways" to keep people safe?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right now—and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby—right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: Does addressing systemic racism in the criminal justice system, as proposed by Clinton, necessarily lead to a reduction in the disproportionate arrest and incarceration rates of young African-American men?

Can you provide evidence from scientific research that supports the claim that young African-American men are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated than young white men for the same offenses, and not due to other factors such as socioeconomic status or crime rates?
If the criminal justice system disproportionately affects young African-American men, why do similar disparities not occur for young white men who engage in the same behaviors?

If systemic racism in the criminal justice system is a significant problem, as you claim, then why haven't you implemented more concrete reforms during your presidency, despite your acknowledgment of its existence?

CLINTON_147.input:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

cqs.cq: Does New York's approach to reducing crime, which Clinton credits, actually prove that a top-down approach with the involvement of multiple stakeholders is the most effective way to address the issue?

Can you provide evidence from New York's crime statistics that suggests the city's approach to community policing and collaboration has been significantly more effective than other cities in reducing crime rates?

If keeping neighborhoods safe is the priority, then why is the Clinton administration's focus on working with communities, faith communities, business communities, and the police not being applied to other social issues, such as poverty and education?
If New York's approach to reducing murders has been effective, then why are other communities still experiencing high crime rates despite implementing similar policies?

CLINTON_17.input:
CLINTON: "let 's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago
We had the worst financial crisis , the Great Recession
the worst since the 1930s
 slashed taxes on the wealthy
failed to invest in the middle class
took their eyes off of Wall Street
created a perfect storm
was in large part because of tax policies
Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis
...
 it did collapse"

cqs.cq: If slashing taxes on the wealthy and failing to invest in the middle class were the primary causes of the Great Recession, then why did those same policies not lead to another economic disaster in the intervening eight years?
Do you have any credible economic data that supports the claim that tax policies alone were the primary cause of the 2008 financial crisis, rather than a complex interplay of factors?
If the economic policies that led to the 2008 crisis were largely the result of tax policies, would that not suggest that the current economic woes are similarly caused by the same policies?
If the policies that led to the Great Recession were so disastrous, why did you, Clinton, support the 2017 tax cuts that benefited the wealthy and largely mirrored those policies?

CLINTON_176_1.input:
CLINTON: "cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president
clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries
There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money
increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states
The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia
There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country
I am deeply concerned about this
Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin
Putin is playing a really tough, long game here
one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee"

cqs.cq: If Russia has successfully used cyber attacks to influence the outcome of the 2016 US presidential election, what would be the likely consequences for the country's cybersecurity if a future president praises and maintains a close relationship with Vladimir Putin?

If airlines are allowed to create and enforce their own policies, why should the rules for overbooking and bumping passengers be any more equitable than the customer service rep's attitude towards the speaker was in their previous experience?

Zewstain__641.input:
