Let her release the e-mails
Why did she delete 33,000"

cqs.cq: If deleting 33,000 emails is a sign of intentional concealment, what effect does this have on the public's perception of Hillary Clinton's honesty and integrity?

Can you provide any credible evidence or expert opinion to support the claim that the deletion of 33,000 emails by Hillary Clinton is a crime, given that the State Department has confirmed that they were personal emails?
If deleting e-mails is a serious offense for a politician, why isn't it also a serious offense for a president to delete e-mails?
If releasing the e-mails is so crucial, then why is Trump unwilling to negotiate and provide them himself?

dberger_74_1.input:
dberger: "There must be a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes.
It is a closed space.
I am allergic to peanuts and almonds
and I am impacted every time I fly.
A nut free zone does not work
since the dust from nuts gets in the closed air system of the plane.
For the time that people are on planes there should be consideration of others who have no control as to the reactions they have to nuts.
For almost all other foods the allergy only occurs if the food is ingested
so you can easily avoid the allergic reaction but not eating the food.
This is not true for many of us with nut allergies
we react if other people are eating the food
since it is an airborne allergy.
I do fly but I have to take multiple Benadryl pills every 4 hours to keep from reacting to the airborne dust of the nuts.
This works for now
but I always wonder when it will no longer be enough.
An epipen is not the answer
as it lasts only look enough for the plane to land
which is not a practical solution when you are flying on a long flight over water
and would certainly be a much greater inconvenience to the other passengers than a ban on nut products on planes if the plane was able to land.
The rules airlines have are ridiculous
Southwest is not nut free
they will not serve nuts
but if you fly a late flight the peanuts are all over the floor and seats.
Some other airlines have the rows around you 'nut free'
but advise you they can do nothing if the person seated next to you brings nuts on and wants to eat them."

cqs.cq: If allowing peanuts and tree nuts on planes poses a significant risk to passengers with airborne nut allergies, then why do airlines not implement a stricter policy to eliminate all nut products from their flights?

Can you provide any scientific evidence to support the claim that a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes would be a more effective solution than the current measures implemented by airlines such as Southwest?
If the airlines can accommodate other passengers with severe food allergies by implementing restrictions on specific foods, why can't they implement a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes?

If an outright ban on nuts on planes is the only way to ensure safety for individuals with severe airborne nut allergies, then why do airlines not implement a stricter enforcement of existing policies against nut consumption on their flights?

dberger_74_2.input:
dberger: "Other airlines with advance notice will not serve nuts
but all airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts
and will not stop the person from eating them if they wish to.
So you can have a 'nut free' flight and the person sitting next to you can take out their package of peanuts and eat away
and the airlines will do nothing to help you.
Again all nuts should be banned from airplanes unless it is your own private plane  then go ahead and eat what you want."

cqs.cq: If airlines have the policy of not serving nuts on advance-notified flights, then why do they not have a similar policy of preventing passengers from bringing and consuming nuts on those flights?

Can you provide a scientific study that supports the claim that banning all nuts on flights would be a more effective solution than the current policy of providing advance notice for passengers with severe nut allergies?
If airlines are not responsible for preventing passengers from eating peanuts, why should they be responsible for accommodating passengers with severe nut allergies by banning all nuts?
If airlines have a policy of not serving nuts but allowing passengers to bring and consume them, doesn't that create a situation where passengers with nut allergies are still vulnerable to harm?

dlpoole_223_1.input:
dlpoole: "Bumping compensation should apply to all carriers
because of the increasing use of regional carriers to serve smaller markets
and their no lesser disruptiveness and potential expense to the traveler.
Passengers may lack check cashing privileges away from their home airport, yet face unplanned and likely elevated expenses after being "bumped."
They should have a mandatory option of cash payment.
An credit card credit, if immediate, would be more secure and as useful to more passengers than either a check or cash.
The proposed compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking
and may be arbitrarily unfair to certain travelers.
The Wall Street Journal recently reproposed a 1977 proposal by the late economist Julian Simon of an auction that would offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat.
The arguments are rather compelling.
See the WSJ, June 8, 2010, "Auctions for Overbooking"  or"

cqs.cq: Would increasing compensation for bumped passengers through an auction system, as proposed by Julian Simon, actually lead to airlines reducing overbooking practices?

Do you have a scientific study that supports the claim that the proposed auction system for bumped passengers, suggested by Julian Simon, is more effective in reducing overbooking than the current compensation limits?
If airlines are incentivized to limit overbooking through higher compensation, why would a mandatory cash payment not be equally effective in preventing disruptions to travelers.
If compensation for being bumped from a flight is not equally applied to all carriers, doesn't that imply that some airlines are inherently less disruptive and expensive than others?

dlpoole_223_2.input:
dlpoole: "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703303904575293011757655060.html
The airlines will overbook so as to optimize their financial results under any given set of caps,
so some passengers will still be involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights.
An auction will more accurately price the delay
and the sellers (the delayed passenger(s)) will be left with no complaint that it was involuntary.
An auction would also force the carriers to face the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction and better inform their flight scheduling decisions.
I recall hearing seats being auctioned by progressive increases in the promised compensation by gate agents,
but that was long, long ago and under far greater seat availability and lower probabilities of cascading delays and subsequent denials of boarding for those who took the compensation.
Those procedures were surely regulated by DOT,
(perhaps when the industry was more heavily regulated,)
so perhaps those earlier rules should be revisited."

cqs.cq: Will the airline's financial optimization under the current system of overbooking actually result in a net loss due to the high costs of customer dissatisfaction, outweighing any potential gains from overbooking?
Do you have any evidence that auctioning off overbooked seats has been implemented successfully in the airline industry, given the complexity of flight scheduling and passenger behavior?

If airlines are allowed to auction off seats to the highest bidder in the event of overbooking, would this model be analogous to how they currently operate, and if so, would this not perpetuate existing power imbalances in the market?
If auctioning off overbooked seats can accurately price the delay and minimize customer dissatisfaction, why not make it a standard practice rather than revisiting outdated regulations?

drgreg_181_1.input:
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: Would forcing airlines to fully reimburse passengers for schedule changes actually result in them becoming more considerate of passengers' plans and less likely to make significant changes?
Do you have any data or research that supports the claim that airlines' schedule changes have a significantly greater impact on passengers than the changes passengers make to their own travel plans?

If airlines are allowed to change flight schedules without penalty for their own operational reasons, why should passengers be forced to pay exorbitant fees to change their itineraries due to the airline's changes?
If airlines can charge passengers hefty fees for making personal itinerary changes, why should they be exempt from compensating passengers for changes they themselves make to the flight schedule?

elizwestley_222.input:
elizwestley: "A peanutfree table is less likely to have smears of peanut butter on/under it.
Risk of exposure is reduced
which is not as good as eliminated but is better than full exposure.
I see the parallel with these flight proposals.
Ban peanut products.
Yes, people will "sneak" them.
However, the risk will still be reduced over the nothing that we are doing now."

cqs.cq: Would banning peanut products on flights be more effective in reducing peanut exposure than implementing a peanut-free table policy, even if some passengers still choose to sneak them?
Can you provide evidence from a scientific study that demonstrates a significant reduction in peanut exposure incidents on tables with peanut-free policies compared to existing measures?
If banning peanut products on flights is seen as a reasonable measure to reduce risk, why not also restrict or ban items that pose similar risks, such as nuts or sharp objects?
If banning peanut products is effective in reducing the risk of exposure, then why not implement a complete ban rather than relying on a partial measure like a peanut-free table?

elizwestley_68.input:
elizwestley: "I've registered my son on a flight as peanutallergic and had the attendant try to hand him a bag of peanuts.
Flight personnel need more education on this."

cqs.cq: If flight personnel are not adequately educated about severe food allergies, what is likely to happen to a passenger with a life-threatening allergy when they are inadvertently exposed to their allergen on a flight?
Can you provide evidence that flight attendants are not already receiving adequate training on food allergies and safety protocols, as claimed by airlines and regulatory bodies?
If flight personnel are expected to be aware of peanut allergies, why are they not also trained to recognize and accommodate other severe food allergies, such as gluten or tree nut allergies?
If flight attendants are not properly educated on handling severe food allergies, then why do airlines claim to prioritize passenger safety?

golff4fun_155.input:
golff4fun: "I think it's important to stress the real reason that aircraft is not returning to the gate.
Once the aircraft pulls away from the jetway, the crew is on the clock.
They are not being paid while sitting at a gate.
And 3 hours is too long to keep people on a grounded airplane."
 < this message is answering to > 
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.

cqs.cq: If airlines are not being paid for crew time while the aircraft is at the gate, would implementing a maximum tarmac delay trigger and requiring deplaning during gate holds effectively reduce the financial burden on airlines, thereby increasing the likelihood of their cooperation with such a policy?

golff4fun_162.input:
golff4fun: "Since weight seems to be the issue with charging extra fees for checked luggage,
the 98 lb person should pay less for a ticket than the 250 pounder.
I have thought that from the very beginning when the airlines introduced this new fee."
 < this message is answering to > 
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.

cqs.cq: Would requiring airlines to charge fees based on actual weight rather than a flat rate for checked luggage lead to a decrease in the number of passengers who check luggage?

If weight-based pricing is truly the concern, then why are airlines not charging extra for larger passengers based on their weight alone, rather than charging all passengers who check bags the same fee?

grayk47__302.input:
grayk47: " you give an illegally (as in you stole it) acquired firearm to a friend to use responsibly
that person accidentally shoots someone
who should be blamed

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the person who received the illegally acquired firearm was the one to ultimately cause harm imply that the person who provided it is also directly responsible for the consequences, whereas Snowden's actions resulted in consequences that were not directly caused by him but rather by a third party?
Do you believe that the principle of shared responsibility for the consequences of actions applies equally to individuals who leak classified information versus those who acquire it illegally?

If a whistleblower shares classified information to a trusted source with the intention of exposing wrongdoing, does the source bear equal responsibility if the information falls into the wrong hands?
If giving stolen information to the media can be considered irresponsible, then should giving a stolen firearm to someone also be considered irresponsible, regardless of their intentions?

hgranato_211.input:
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: Does the risk of a severe allergic reaction justify the significant logistical and economic burdens associated with banning peanuts in the airline industry?
Can you provide evidence from reputable medical sources that the likelihood of a serious reaction to tree nuts is indeed similar to that of peanuts?
If the airlines can take precautions to mitigate severe tree nut allergies, why can't they also take similar precautions for peanut allergies?
If the risk of severe reactions from tree nuts is similar to that of peanuts, then why should peanuts be singled out for stricter regulations rather than tree nuts?

howie_201.input:
howie: "First, stop reading that propaganda magazine.
Publications like that only serve to create fear in minds like yours.
Second, how old is your kid?
If under 5, relax the sensitivity will probably go away by the time he is 5.
Third, go to a real doctor  not an allergist and see if there is really even a problem at all.
This supposed plague of food allergies is the result of very clever advertising by this profession of pseudoscientists.
Allergists are not doctors.
I sincerely doubt you "know plenty of people who will die if they do have peanuts or breathe in peanut dust".
Almost noone is actually that allergic.
Lot's of people think they are much worse off than they really are.
Methinks you have an agenda.
Highly suspicious that the child of a physician who is hyper aware of bad things that can happen coincidentally has not one, but three life threatening allergies.
Have you heard of Munchasen by Proxy?
Do you realize that most kids have mild reactions to various food items that they invariably grow out of by the age of 5?
Food allergies have to be the most overblown imagined health problem of our time.
Hypochondriacs all."
 < this message is answering to > 
jsooudi: "I'm a physician, epidemiologist, and mother to a four year old boy with allergies to milk, peanuts and egg.
My son's dairy allergy is severe,
and he has had numerous lifethreatening anaphylactic reactions to trace amounts of milk,
which required multiple doses of epinephrine and trips to the Emergency Department.
Tests indicate that his peanut allergy is worse,
but fortunately he has only been exposed once to a peanut;
he put one in his mouth and had a relatively mild  reaction.
I've traveled with my children
and despite calling ahead, making requests, and reminding employees at the door, I've rarely had respect, let alone consistency, in any kind of peanutfree buffer zone or flight.
Several years ago Continental Airlines customer service headquarters informed me that they would serve peanuts on all flights as they were unable to guarantee a peanut free flight.
(So why not hand out weapons since they can't guarantee a weapon free flight either?)
I've sat with my epi pen in hand on a filthy flight with visible peanut crumbs on the floor while a flight attendant insisted on offering peanuts to the passengers around me because "it was their right."
Fortunately for me, my son's peanut allergy is not severe enough that it prohibits us from air travel.
Now that he is old enough to not put things in his mouth, and to protect himself, we are safer.
However, I know of many, many others in the allergy community, children and adults who simply can NOT fly.
My son's dairy allergy is quite severe.
The world would be a much safer place for us if no one consumed milk near him.
If his skin touches anything that once touched milk, even if it was partially cleaned, he will get severe hives.
If he consumes even less than a drop, within seconds his lips, eyes and face will swell, he will be covered in hives, vomit, and be gasping for breath.
Without epinephrine he would probably die within minutes.
But milk is ubiquitous,
and milk allergy relatively uncommon,
so we must protect ourselves.
Peanut allergy is common,
and it is a simple step to serve an alternative peanut based snacks for a short period of time.
So why is this a big problem?
The vast majority of potential reactions would be eliminated by simply avoiding snacks that have peanuts or peanut butter as an ingredient.
Peanut oil is known to contain very little of the actual peanut protein,
and would be of little risk in an airborne environment.
As a physician, I have responded to the call from airline staff asking for emergency medical assistance.
I am well aware of how expensive and inconvenient it is to ground a plane.
In addition, most epipens come in two pack doses,
each of which are good for maybe 10 to 15 minutes.
Which in a severe anaphylactic reaction is simply not enough time between the beginning of a reaction and the patient reaching EMS.
I've found that other passengers, as a rule, are extremely supportive,
and are more than happy to help with a fellow passengers safety.
I think the people commenting on this site would react entirely differently were they seated next to an allergic child on a plane.
Of course they would refrain from eating peanuts for a few hours if they knew it would hurt someone they were looking in the face.
But I am sympathetic to individuals who are unhappy with yet another discomfort inflicted on air travelers.
This restriction is designed to protect people with allergies from the airlines callous disregard for cleanliness and for our safety, not from our fellow passengers.
"Hi.  My name is Steven.  I am 4 years old.
I am allergic to peanuts, eggs and cow milk.
If I eat a peanut I'll get sick.
I ate a nut one time and got a big bump on my lip and it swelled up and it was hard to breathe.
It was scary and my dad gave me some medicine that made it better.
I would like for them to not give out peanuts so I won't get sick because I'm allergic.
Everybody should drink Sprite and eat Pringles and Pretzels.""

cqs.cq: Does the prevalence of severe food allergies, as described by Dr. Soudi, justify the significant inconvenience and restriction of serving peanuts on flights, given the potential risks to the allergic individuals and the relatively low risk of anaphylactic reactions to peanut dust in an airborne environment?

Can you provide a scientific study or medical evidence to support your claim that most children with allergies will grow out of them by the age of 5, considering your own child's severe and persistent allergies?

If a 4-year-old's peanut allergy is severe enough to warrant a medical emergency, does that not justify taking precautions to accommodate his needs, just as we would for other life-threatening conditions?

If you claim that food allergies are overblown and not a significant threat, then why do you think a child like Steven, who has experienced a severe reaction to a single peanut, is not entitled to a safe environment on an airplane?

howie_208.input:
howie: "Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from eating peanuts?
Didn't think so.
Most food allergies are imagined.
You clearly have a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy.
If someone is actually that allergic, they should stay home and not inconvenience the rest of us."
 < this message is answering to > 
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Do the risks associated with peanut allergies and the potential for life-threatening reactions outweigh the perceived inconvenience to the majority of passengers in order to justify a full ban of peanut products on airlines?
Do you have any peer-reviewed studies or credible medical evidence to support your claim that most food allergies are imagined, contradicting the overwhelming consensus in the medical community?

If airline food choices are considered a necessary choice due to consumer demand, why not consider the safety concerns of a vulnerable population as a necessary choice in deciding to eliminate peanuts from flights?

If the airline industry's refusal to ban peanuts is based on the claim that most food allergies are imagined, then why are you, as a physician and author on the subject, advocating for a ban that contradicts your own assertion?

howie_213.input:
howie: "While I still dispute whether your reaction will be as severe as you believe, at least you realize that it is your responsibility to take precautions.

and should not be an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others."

hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,

given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)

Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: Does the airline industry's lack of comprehensive allergy protocols lead to severe reactions in passengers with food allergies, thereby causing them to miss flights or require emergency medical attention?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that individuals with severe allergies are always capable of taking proactive steps to prevent exposure?
If a severe peanut allergy is not an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others, why would a severe tree nut allergy be any different?
If airlines are not responsible for accommodating severe allergies, then why should they be required to accommodate other health conditions that are not as life-threatening?

howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Do the perceived health risks associated with peanuts, as exaggerated by some individuals, outweigh their nutritional benefits and convenience in everyday life?
Do you have any credible scientific studies that support the claim that peanut allergy diagnoses are predominantly the result of anxiety or imagined allergies rather than actual medical conditions?

If people with severe peanut allergies are advised to avoid all environments where peanuts are present, wouldn't that also apply to people with a severe allergy to, say, gluten or shellfish, who are also ubiquitous in public spaces?
If the risk of severe allergic reactions from peanuts is so low, why should people with a diagnosed peanut allergy be barred from flying altogether?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: If peanut-free flights are possible, as shown by Northwest's example, why do airlines still allow peanut products on board flights, despite the potential life-threatening risks to passengers with severe allergies?
Do you have any scientific evidence that proves airline buffer zones are ineffective in preventing severe reactions from peanut dust, as you claim?
If smokers were allowed to continue smoking on flights despite the risks to non-smokers, why should peanuts be exempt from similar restrictions to protect passengers with life-threatening allergies?

If airlines have successfully implemented smoke-free zones in the past to protect passengers with respiratory issues, why can't they implement peanut-free zones to protect passengers with severe peanut allergies?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: If peanut allergies can cause anaphylactic reactions with even microscopic amounts of peanuts, why do airlines still not provide peanut-free flight options as a standard accommodation for passengers with life-threatening allergies?

Can you provide evidence from a peer-reviewed medical journal that supports the claim that the risk of peanut allergy reactions on planes is higher than the risk of peanut-related accidents from a plane crash?

If peanuts pose such a unique risk on planes due to their tendency to break into airborne particles and cause anaphylactic reactions, why should they not be treated as hazardous materials that require special precautions similar to those taken with flammable materials or sharp objects?

If banning peanuts on planes is a necessary measure to protect individuals with life-threatening allergies, then shouldn't airlines also be held responsible for the consequences of failing to implement such a ban?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: Do airlines' failure to prioritize passenger comfort and space in their aircraft designs cause a significant decrease in passenger satisfaction and overall enjoyment of air travel?

Do you have any data or expert opinions from the aviation industry that suggest airlines are prioritizing comfort and ergonomics in their seating designs over the current focus on maximizing space efficiency?

If airlines prioritize luxury features like in-flight entertainment and meal options over ergonomic comfort, why should passengers expect significant improvements to be made to seating space in economy class?

If passengers are willing to endure the discomfort of economy class seats for the sake of saving space, then why not prioritize luxury amenities in first class instead of allocating them to a select few?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: Would the loss of a customer like the author, who travels frequently with their pet, have a significant impact on the airline's overall revenue and customer base?
Do you think airlines have a responsibility to prioritize customer and pet convenience over potential concerns about safety and liability when considering changes to their pet travel policies?

If airlines can accommodate passengers who have behavioral issues, such as loud children or unruly adults, why can't they also accommodate well-behaved pets traveling in carriers secured by seat belts?

If the convenience and comfort of human passengers are prioritized over those of traveling animals, why should pet owners be expected to bear the financial burden and stress of cargo travel when they could be accommodated in the cabin?

mfball__143.input:
mfball: "we listen to the top five Democrats
the Republicans had the top eleven or so in their debate
Chafee seemed like a trainwreck in the debate
O'Malley did alright
You might be right about his chances at getting the nomination
some candidates' chances could be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting
People were swearing up and down that Bernie didn't have a shot
no one had ever heard of him
Hillary was the only one getting airtime
now he's getting a lot of attention
 he's a competitive candidate
 I don't know a lot about O'Malley
nobody's been talking about him or interviewing him
I don't think he came off as a "sideshow" candidate in the debate
If he started getting more attention, I imagine he could probably pull numbers at least as good as the lowest of the Republicans that are still being talked about"

cqs.cq: Would increased media coverage for a candidate like O'Malley lead to improved public perception and, subsequently, higher poll numbers, regardless of the quality of their performance in debates?

Do you have any evidence to suggest that media coverage is a more significant factor in determining a candidate's chances of nomination than other factors, such as their policy positions or voter support?

If media coverage can significantly boost a candidate's chances, why does Bernie Sanders' rise in popularity not demonstrate that media attention alone can be a decisive factor in a candidate's success?
If O'Malley performed relatively well in the debate, why doesn't he receive more media attention and coverage compared to other Democratic candidates?

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!
Personally I have anxiety issues
and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
I think it goes a LONG ways to alleviate frustration
if we were informed in detail every 30 minutes.
I have been stranded on a plane 3 times
thankfully not more than 1 1/2 hours
but on one of these flights we were informed regularly along the way
and it made all the difference."

cqs.cq: Do you think the 2-hour delay limit will effectively alleviate frustration and anxiety in passengers, or will it simply shift the burden to airlines to prevent delays without addressing the underlying causes of flight delays?

Do you have any evidence from studies on anxiety disorders that suggests being confined to an enclosed space for up to 3 hours has a significantly more detrimental effect on individuals than being confined for 2 hours?

If flight delays can be alleviated with regular updates, would not providing similar updates during other forms of prolonged confinement, such as prison sentences, also alleviate the suffering of inmates?

If being subjected to anxiety-inducing delays is a legitimate concern for passengers, why should airlines be held accountable for preventing such experiences when they are not responsible for the causes of those delays, such as bad weather or air traffic control issues?

secretcurse__137.input:
secretcurse: "Don't hold your breath for the Green Party Presidential Debate on any of our major news networks
a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public
there's no obligation to give them equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election
Clinton is extremely likely to win the Democratic nomination
Sanders has a shot at beating her
O'Malley, Webb, and Chafee are all sideshow candidates in the primary
just like the nominees from the Green, Libertarian, and Communist parties will be in the general election
Everyone should be allowed to express themselves in public places freely, but a cable news network isn't a public place"

cqs.cq: Does allowing privately owned networks to selectively choose which candidates to feature in debates not undermine the principle of equal public expression that they claim to uphold?

Can you provide a scientific source that supports the notion that privately owned networks have no obligation to provide equal time to minor party candidates, despite their right to express their views in public places?
If private networks have the right to choose which candidates to give airtime to, would they also have the right to exclude candidates from underrepresented communities if they deem them unelectable?
If private networks are allowed to choose which candidates to give airtime to, does that not create an unfair advantage for the major parties and undermine the democratic process?

secretcurse__139.input:
secretcurse: "The first debate was already limited to five people
According to the FEC
171 people have officially declared their candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination with the FEC (sort by party to see the 171 people a bit easier)
Do you think every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate"

cqs.cq: Do you think a fair shot at the debate would be compromised if the current five-person limit is maintained, given the large number of candidates who have officially declared their candidacy?

Do you have any evidence or precedent to suggest that limiting the first debate to a specific number of candidates is a fair or effective way to ensure diverse representation of the 171 candidates who have filed with the FEC?
If a debate is limited to five participants, would that not be comparable to limiting a music festival to only five performers out of hundreds of talented artists?

If a candidate's ability to participate in debates is determined by their ability to express themselves, then does that mean the 166 candidates who won't make the cut are inherently less deserving of being heard?

smg_72.input:
smg: "It has become abundantly clear that commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits.
A change of environment, which can only be imposed from outside the industry is needed.
Imposition of common sense regulations,
would level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to costcut in this area.
The results would be better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which the airlines compete without fear of being undercut.
This goes for most of the proposed new regulations.
I sincerely believe that these regulations are in the best interests of both airlines and passengers."

cqs.cq: If imposition of common sense regulations does indeed level the playing field, would it not create an environment where airlines are incentivized to prioritize profits over customer satisfaction, thus undermining the intended outcome?

Can you provide evidence from the airline industry that demonstrates the effectiveness of imposed regulations in improving customer service and preventing cost-cutting measures without negatively impacting airline profits?
Would imposing common sense regulations on the airline industry similarly level the playing field for other industries that engage in a "race to the bottom," such as healthcare or education?

If we need external intervention to impose common sense regulations on the airline industry, then does this not undermine the airlines' ability to self-regulate and make decisions in the best interests of their customers?

smr_174_1.input:
smr: "The problem of whether to deplane or not is a tricky one.
On one side is the fact that sitting for an excessive amount of time is uncomfortable at best and unhealthy at worst.
However, on the other side there will be considerable time lost with the deplaning and reboarding.
One item which should be addressed is food and drink.
If the airline would normally have food for the passengers on that flight it seems silly to deny access to anything more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water.
This happened to my husband last week on a Delta flight from Newark to Amsterdam.
The passengers were sitting on the plane for over six hours, at the gate,
but they were only offered one bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice.
The plane eventually took off at approximately 1 a.m.,
when it should have taken off at 6.40 the previous evening."

cqs.cq: Does the airline's policy of providing minimal snacks and drinks to passengers stuck on the plane for extended periods contribute to passengers' discomfort and decreased satisfaction, potentially affecting their overall travel experience?

Do you have any data or studies that support the claim that the time spent deplaning and reboarding is considerably longer than the benefits of providing passengers with more substantial food and drink options during prolonged delays?
If airlines are willing to provide a full meal on long flights, why not provide a similar level of service when planes are grounded at the gate for extended periods?

If the airline is unwilling to provide adequate food and drink to passengers who are forced to remain seated for extended periods, does that not constitute inhumane treatment, especially when they are being charged for their flights?

smr_174_2.input:
smr: "The dinner was not served until the normal point in the flight, somewhere over the Atlantic!
Allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not give them access to food and drink,
but would let them move around.
However, when passengers expect food to be served on a flight they will often depend on that being served
and an excessive delay in serving meals could be hazardous to some people's health,
especially when on a connecting flight
so there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport."

cqs.cq: If passengers are at risk of health hazards due to delayed meal service, why not allow them to disembark into a holding area to access food and drinks before the scheduled meal time?

Don't you think that providing passengers with access to food and drinks in a holding area, even if not served on the plane, would outweigh the potential benefits of keeping them confined to the aircraft?

If serving dinner on a flight is delayed due to flight duration, why would allowing passengers to exit the plane into a holding area not be an acceptable solution to alleviate the resulting health risks?

If passengers are allowed to leave the plane into a holding area to alleviate health risks due to excessive delays in meal service, why not allow them to leave the plane to access food and drink as well?

travellots_133_1.input:
travellots: "There should be no discrimination in how a passenger is bumped or compensated just because they may have paid less for a ticket or used frequent flyer miles.
Airline tickets are not lottery tickets.
One does not purchase a ticket hoping to reach a certain destination.
Same as if one pays $4 for a cup of coffee or $1, the cup is supposed to have coffee in it.
The price does not dictate that "maybe" you will get the product or service.
Also, the airline decides what prices or miles are used to purchase a promise to get you from point A to point B.
If they can not afford to give  a ticket for that price, they should not sell it.
When you reserve a ticket, the assumption is that you will be taken from point A to point B by the times given by the airline.
A passenger does not purchase a ticket just to see if maybe they can get somewhere because they have nothing better to do."

cqs.cq: Does the airline's business model, which relies on selling cheaper tickets to some passengers while promising a service that may not be guaranteed, inherently create an expectation that passengers will be bumped or compensated differently based on their ticket price or loyalty program status?

Can you provide any reputable industry or legal precedent that supports the notion that airline tickets are a promise of service rather than a commodity that can be fulfilled or not, regardless of the price paid?
If an airline sells a ticket with a promise of transportation, would it not be akin to selling a cup of coffee with a guarantee of containing coffee, rather than a gamble with an uncertain outcome?

If airline tickets are not lottery tickets, then why should passengers who pay less for a ticket or use frequent flyer miles be treated as if they are less deserving of a guaranteed seat or fair compensation if bumped?

travellots_133_2.input:
travellots: "If compensation is not high enough, the airlines will not have an incentive to schedule properly.
It is not fair to allow airlines to discriminate against lower fared passengers or "free" passengers
since it is the airline, not the passenger or government, who gave that passenger a seat.
Otherwise, airlines can advertise low fares or con you into using them to build up your "miles" and then always bump you for someone who paid more.
In away,it is the same as being able to increase your ticket price anytime after purchase.
When you are bumped, there are a lot of hidden extra costs
It irks me that airlines seem to be treating passengers more and more as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports and not get to where the airline promised to bring them.
Again, the airline sets the agreed price or miles for a seat, no one else.
The incentives to the airline should be to get all confirmed passengers (regardless of price paid) to the destination promised."

cqs.cq: Would lower compensation for airlines actually lead to better scheduling practices, or would it simply allow them to prioritize revenue over passenger satisfaction?

Do you have any evidence from the airline industry or economics that suggests airlines would not prioritize efficient scheduling and passenger satisfaction when offered a guaranteed revenue stream from confirmed passengers?

If airlines can discriminate against lower-fared passengers and bump them for higher-paying customers, why can't restaurants or hotels similarly prioritize and bump customers who booked at lower rates?

If the airline's primary incentive is to get all confirmed passengers to their destination, then why do they prioritize seating and bumping passengers based on price rather than a first-come, first-served basis?

zuclinator_125.input:
zuclinator: "I know Delta serves peanuts
as I travel to and from Detroit on Delta.
I was really surprised to learn this
as I didn't know until I was on the plane and in the air.
shouldn't they tell people before they pay for a flight?
Oh and the two row minimum around a person with a peanut allergy is a joke.
Someone with a peanut allergy is not going to be protected by that!"

cqs.cq: Does Delta's failure to disclose peanut serving information before passengers pay for a flight cause them to be held liable for any potential allergic reactions that occur onboard?

Do you have any evidence from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) or airline industry guidelines that explicitly requires airlines to inform passengers about in-flight snack options prior to purchase?

If airlines are required to disclose allergenic in-flight food options like peanuts, why wouldn't they also be obligated to clearly inform passengers about other potential allergens or irritants on board, such as strong perfumes or cleaning products?
If airlines are aware of the severe risks posed by peanuts, why do they still serve them on flights when passengers with life-threatening allergies have already paid for their tickets?

TRUMP_114_1.input:
TRUMP: "we have been told through investigative reporting that he owes about $ 650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks
You learn a lot from financial disclosure
That I can tell you
you should go down and take a look at that
I 'm extremely underleveraged
The report that said $ 650
a lot of friends of mine that know my business
It 's not a lot of money relative to what I had
The buildings that were in question , they said in the same report , which was—actually , it was n't even a bad story , to be honest with you , but the buildings are worth $ 3.9 billion
the $ 650 is n't even on that
it 's not $ 650
It 's much less than that
I could give you a list of banks
I would—if that would help you , I would give you a list of banks
These are very fine institutions
very fine banks
I could do that very quickly
I am very underleveraged
I have a great company
I have a tremendous income
the reason I say that is not in a braggadocios way
It 's because it 's about time that this country had somebody running it that has an idea about money
we have $ 20 trillion in debt"

cqs.cq: If Trump is "extremely underleveraged" as he claims, then why does he owe $650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks?
Can you provide a credible source or expert financial analysis to support your claim that you are "extremely underleveraged" when your reported debt is approximately $650 million?

If Trump claims he is "extremely underleveraged" while owing $650 million, wouldn't his situation be analogous to a household being underwater on their mortgage while still being described as financially stable?
If having $20 trillion in debt is a concern, then shouldn't the amount Trump owes to Wall Street and foreign banks, no matter how he downplays it, also be a concern for the American people?

TRUMP_114_2.input:
TRUMP: "our country 's a mess
it 's one thing to have $ 20 trillion in debt
Our airports are like from a third world country
You land at LaGuardia , you land at Kennedy , you land at LAX , you land at Newark , and you come in from Dubai and Qatar and you see these incredible—you come in from China , you see these incredible airports
we 've become a third world country
our bridges are good
everything 's in great shape
our airports
the worst of all things has happened
We owe $ 20 trillion
we 're a mess
We have n't even started
we 've spent $ 6 trillion in the Middle East
according to a report that I just saw
Whether it 's 6 or 5
 it looks like it 's 6
we could have rebuilt our country twice
it 's really a shame
it 's politicians like Secretary Clinton that have caused this problem
Our country has tremendous problems
We 're a debtor nation
We 're a serious debtor nation
we have a country that needs new roads , new tunnels , new bridges , new airports , new schools , new hospitals
we don't have the money
it 's been squandered on so many of your ideas"

cqs.cq: If the $20 trillion debt and neglected infrastructure are the result of politicians' decisions, then what specific policies or actions would you propose to prevent similar economic mismanagement in the future?
Can you provide a credible source that supports the claim that the $6 trillion spent in the Middle East could have been used to rebuild the United States twice?

If the airports in the United States are deemed comparable to those in third-world countries, would that not also imply that the country's infrastructure, such as its roads, bridges, and schools, is similarly underdeveloped?

If the US has spent $6 trillion in the Middle East, which is equivalent to rebuilding the country twice, shouldn't that money have been spent on domestic infrastructure and development instead of exacerbating America's debt and third-world airport conditions?

TRUMP_121_1.input:
TRUMP: "I do think it's time
it's all words
it's all sound bites
I built an unbelievable company
Some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world
real estate assets anywhere in the world
beyond the United States, in Europe, lots of different places
It's an unbelievable company
on occasion, four times, we used certain laws that are there
when Secretary Clinton talks about people that didn't get paid, first of all, they did get paid a lot, but taken advantage of the laws of the nation
if you want to change the laws, you've been there a long time, change the laws
you've been there a long time,
I take advantage of the laws of the nation
I'm running a company
My obligation right now is to do well for myself, my family, my employees, for my companies
that's what I do
what she doesn't say is that tens of thousands of people that are unbelievably happy and that love me"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that Trump built a successful company, as he claims, necessarily imply that he would be a successful and effective president?
Can you provide evidence from a credible business or economics expert that suggests building a large real estate empire is an indicator of a leader's ability to effectively govern a country?

If a successful businessperson can claim that they are simply taking advantage of existing laws to achieve their goals, why should that not also be a valid argument for individuals who use tax loopholes or exploit societal inequalities to improve their own economic situations?

If building an "unbelievable company" is a justification for taking advantage of laws, then shouldn't we be held accountable for the consequences of our own success, rather than shifting the focus to the perceived benefits?

TRUMP_121_2.input:
TRUMP: "I'll give you an example
We're just opening up on Pennsylvania Avenue right next to the White House
if I don't get there one way, I'm going to get to Pennsylvania Avenue another
we're opening the Old Post Office
I'm a year ahead of schedule
that's what this country should be doing
We build roads
they cost two and three and four times what they're supposed to cost
We buy products for our military
they come in at costs that are so far above what they were supposed to be
we don't have people that know what they're doing
When we look at the budget, the budget is bad to a large extent
we have people that have no idea as to what to do and how to buy
The Trump International is way under budget
way ahead of schedule
we should be able to do that for our country"

cqs.cq: If the Trump Organization's experience with the Trump International is indicative of their competence in managing large-scale projects, why can't they apply the same level of efficiency to government projects like the Old Post Office renovation?
Can you provide evidence from any previous construction projects you've undertaken that demonstrate your ability to manage budgets and timelines without significant overruns?
If a private business like the Trump International can be completed under budget and ahead of schedule, why can't the federal government do the same with its projects?

If the Trump International was completed under budget and ahead of schedule, then why can't the same level of efficiency be replicated in government projects like the ones mentioned on Pennsylvania Avenue and for the military?

TRUMP_125_1.input:
TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order
If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country
when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's—I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long
I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just—just came in
We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very—I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States
We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in hell
it's so dangerous
You walk down the street, you get shot
In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st
I'm saying, where is this
Is this a war-torn country
What are we doing
we have to stop the violence
In a place like Chicago, where thousands of people have been killed, thousands over the last number of years
almost 4,000 have been killed since Barack Obama became president"

cqs.cq: Does the state of inner cities, as described by Trump, necessarily lead to a conclusion that the country is on the verge of collapse as he suggests?
Do you have any credible evidence that suggests the Fraternal Order of Police endorsement is not a self-serving gesture, rather than an unbiased assessment of your policies?

If a city like Chicago is considered a war-torn country due to its high crime rates, wouldn't that imply that other countries with similar crime rates are also war-torn, regardless of their geographical location?

If law and order are essential for the country to exist, then why does the current administration's policies seem to be contributing to the lawlessness and violence in cities like Chicago, which has seen thousands of deaths since President Obama took office?

TRUMP_125_2.input:
TRUMP: "almost 4,000 people in Chicago have been killed
 whether or not in a place like Chicago you do stop and frisk, which worked very well, Mayor Giuliani is here, worked very well in New York
It brought the crime rate way down
you take the gun away from criminals that shouldn't be having it
We have gangs roaming the street
in many cases, they're illegally here, illegal immigrants
they have guns
they shoot people
we have to be very strong
we have to be very vigilant
We have to be—we have to know what we're doing
 our police, in many cases, are afraid to do anything
We have to protect our inner cities
African-American communities are being decimated by crime, decimated
No"

cqs.cq: Does the implementation of stop and frisk policies actually effectively reduce crime rates, or do they merely displace crime to other areas and communities?
Do you have any credible evidence or studies that support the claim that stop-and-frisk policies are effective in reducing crime rates in the long term, particularly in African-American communities?

If stop and frisk worked effectively in reducing crime in New York City under Giuliani, why would its implementation in Chicago not be similarly effective in reducing crime in predominantly African-American communities?
If stop and frisk was effective in New York, why would it not be effective in addressing the high crime rate in Chicago, which shares similar issues of gang violence and illegal immigration?

TRUMP_127.input:
TRUMP: "you're wrong
It went before a judge, who was a very against-police judge
It was taken away from her
our mayor, our new mayor, refused to go forward with the case
They would have won an appeal
If you look at it, throughout the country, there are many places where it's allowed"

cqs.cq: Does the mayor's decision to not pursue the case despite the potential for an appeal indicate a bias against the plaintiff, potentially influencing the outcome of similar cases in the future?
Can you provide a credible source to support the claim that the judge in question was "against-police" and that this bias affected the outcome of the case?
If a judge's personal bias against the police is a sufficient reason to dismiss a case, does that not imply that the judge's bias against Trump would have been a valid reason to dismiss his claims?
If the case was indeed strong enough to win an appeal, then why did the mayor refuse to proceed with it?

TRUMP_129.input:
TRUMP: "the argument is that we have to take the guns away from these people that have them
they are bad people that shouldn't have them
These are felons
These are people that are bad people that shouldn't be
when you have 3,000 shootings in Chicago from January 1st
when you have 4,000 people killed in Chicago by guns, from the beginning of the presidency of Barack Obama, his hometown

MT_14.input:

cqs.cq: If companies are allowed to present misleading information in fine print, do you think it's likely to cause consumers to make uninformed financial decisions that ultimately harm their financial well-being?

If we consider it deceptive to present misleading information on a credit card letter, would it not also be deceptive to require large warnings on food products with high salt and fat content if the warnings themselves might be misleading or confusing to consumers?

If we're holding credit card companies accountable for being transparent about their charges, why are we not holding food manufacturers equally accountable for accurately representing the health impacts of their products?

ND_23.input:

As far as my tax returns , you do n't learn that much from tax returns"

cqs.cq: If Trump's staff taking the Fifth Amendment and the person responsible for setting up the illegal server are considered a sign of a cover-up, then why should the public be less concerned about his tax returns potentially revealing similar wrongdoing?
Do you have any evidence from a credible source that taking the Fifth Amendment or using a private server constitutes a deliberate act of wrongdoing that warrants public disgrace?
If a president's staff taking the Fifth Amendment is considered "disgraceful," would it not also be considered "disgraceful" if a private citizen's staff or family members did the same?
If intentionally mishandling sensitive information is considered disgraceful, then isn't attempting to obstruct investigations by having staff take the Fifth Amendment equally egregious?

CLINTON_244_1.input:
CLINTON: "let me start by saying , words matter
they really matter when you are president
Words matter when you run for president
I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them
It is essential that America 's word be good
I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe
I 've talked with a number of them
I want to—on behalf of myself , and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people , say that , you know , our word is good
It 's also important that we look at the entire global situation
There 's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran
personally , I 'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that
Donald never tells you what he would do
Would he have started a war ?
Would he have bombed Iran ?"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's emphasis on the importance of America's word being good imply that the threat of war or military action against Iran would be an effective means of maintaining that credibility?

Do you have any evidence from your diplomatic interactions that demonstrates the majority of foreign leaders share your confidence in America's word, given the current global situation and potential risks associated with Iran?

If the reliability of a nation's word is contingent upon the character of its president, would the United States' commitment to honoring its defense treaties be more or less secure under a president who frequently disregards facts and contradicts himself?
If Clinton's words are indeed good, then why did the US have to resort to imposing sanctions on North Korea despite Clinton's promise to honor mutual defense treaties with South Korea?
